meta.title: Cybersecurity Fundamentals: A Real-World Perspective
meta.author: Dr Kutub Thakur & Dr Al-Sakib Khan Pathan

parts.title: Understanding Computer Basics and History
parts.body: Computers are electronic devices that use input to transform raw data into meaningful output. Modern systems comprise hardware and software. Hardware involves components like the CPU, and input/output devices, while software might involve the operating system and applications. The history of computers reveals an evolution beginning with Charles Babbage's designs from the 19th century, leading to modern generations of computing. These devices are now integral to daily activities, demonstrating innovations across hardware and software layers.

parts.title: Generations of Computers 1 & 2
parts.body: First Generation (1937–1946): Early computers like ENIAC relied on vacuum tubes. These machines were enormous, weighing about 30 tons and using 20,000 vacuum tubes. Power dips were reported when they were switched on due to their massive consumption. Second Generation (1947–1962): These used transistors, which were more efficient and smaller. UNIVAC 1 became the first commercial computer using transistor technology. IBM launched its 650 and 700 series. During this period, assembly languages gained popularity.

parts.title: Understanding DoS and DDoS Attacks
parts.body: DoS stands for Denial of Service, where hackers flood a server with excessive requests, overwhelming it to disrupt functionality. This blocks legitimate users from accessing services. Symptoms for users involve website inaccessibility, delays, and increased spam. Detection systems and firewalls can help mitigate these attacks. Within DoS, there are various types like DNS server attacks and SYN flood attacks. DDoS, or Distributed Denial of Service, is more severe than DoS. It involves multiple sources, making traffic harder to block. In both, the goal is to jam the victim's server, hindering access to legitimate users. While DoS attacks originate from a single source, DDoS leverages multiple sources simultaneously, complicating prevention efforts.

parts.title: Petya Cyberattack Overview
parts.body: Petya cyberattack, unleashed on May 27, 2017, targeted critical infrastructure like power grids and banks, mainly in Ukraine. This ransomware attack encrypted valuable data and demanded ransom for decryption keys. Its impact extended beyond Ukraine, affecting global businesses and emphasizing the importance of robust cybersecurity measures. Victims were faced with choosing between paying ransom or losing their data permanently, demonstrating the attack's severe consequences on essential services. Cyberattacks like Petya highlight the fragile nature of digital security in critical systems. The attack's widespread disruption underscores the need for PREPAREDNESS against ransomware threats. As with many cyberattacks, implementing effective security protocols and keeping systems updated are essential defenses. This emphasizes that inadequate security can lead to significant financial loss, reputational damage, and operational disruption.

parts.title: Recent Cyberattacks: Petya and US Election Hacking
parts.body:
Summary of Recent Cyberattacks and Their Impact

Petya Ransomware, first spotted in March 2016, evolved to a more potent version on May 27, 2017. It exploited the EternalBlue vulnerability in Windows systems, similar to WannaCry. This new version affected countries like Ukraine and Germany, plus energy firms, causing damages estimated at $10 billion. The ransom locked systems by rewriting the Master Boot Record, leading to service disruptions in the energy sector, thus amplifying economic impact across various businesses. Also significant is the 2016 US Election Hacking, linked to Russian cyber actors. Reports indicate systematic meddling through hacking of Democratic National Committee emails and dissemination of false narratives via social media. This manipulation aimed to influence voter opinions ahead of the election, raising discussions about election security integrity.

parts.title: Importance of Computer Security Measures
parts.body: Computers are a vital part of modern life, influencing everything from communication and commerce to entertainment and work. With their increasing use, security issues have also escalated. These threats fall into two categories: physical threats and cybersecurity threats. Physical threats are further classified as overt and covert, while cybersecurity involves threats to computer security, network security, and data security. Cyberattacks have grown more sophisticated as technologies advance, often causing millions in losses and affecting societal stability. To mitigate these threats, one important measure is implementing firewall settings. A firewall acts as the first line of defense, monitoring both incoming and outgoing traffic to ensure it originates from trusted sources and authorized ports. Many free and paid firewall software options are available, like ZoneAlarm Pro and Comodo Firewall. It's advised to pay for high-quality software rather than rely on free versions, as paid software offers more robust protection and features. Newer threats demand ever-more sophisticated defenses like firewalls to secure computers effectively.

parts.title: The Importance of Effective Password Management
parts.body: Password Management According to Symantec Norton, in 2017, over 34% of people faced losses due to password hacking, costing $172 billion globally. Common issues include simple passwords like 123456 and password reuse, which increase security risks. Research in 2018 highlighted this risky behavior, especially in government sectors. Effective password management involves: - Creating strong passwords (12-20 characters, with varied characters). - Avoiding reused or easy passwords. - Implementing biometrics and multi-factor authentication. Following these strategies can fortify your online security, deterring cybercriminals.

parts.title: Biometric and Two-Factor Authentication
parts.body: Biometric authentication combines biometric data with passwords for enhanced security on mobile devices. However, there are privacy concerns due to data access from biometric scans, but it benefits sensitive locations (e.g., airports) by preventing terrorist activities. Two-factor authentication adds security by requiring a passcode sent to your phone after a password, which is unique and time-sensitive to prevent compromise. It is used by major platforms like Google and Facebook and supports methods like biometric input for additional security.

parts.title: Advanced Cybersecurity Algorithms and Prediction Tools
parts.body: Machine learning is crucial in IT, enabling systems like intrusion detection systems (IDS), which detect cyberattacks. IDS uses algorithms to track suspicious activities by comparing traffic patterns. Genetic algorithms (GA), based on evolutionary theory, optimize this by simulating natural selection, effectively identifying attack patterns. Additionally, statistical approaches like principal component analysis (PCA) and Markovian models further refine detection accuracy. Important for cyberattack prediction is analyzing system vulnerabilities to foresee potential attacks and construct cyberattack trees, simulating potential attacker decisions. This method boasts about 95% accuracy, aiding in proactive security strengthening. Numerous tools help identify cyberattack probabilities, essential for robust cybersecurity.

parts.title: Two-Factor Authentication and Application-Specific Passwords
parts.body: # Two-Factor Authentication 🔐 Multi-factor authentication is a crucial tool in cybersecurity, enhancing security by requiring multiple credentials to access systems. Typically, this includes something you know, like a password or PIN, something you have, like a one-time password (OTP) sent to your phone, and something you are, like a fingerprint. Activation of two-factor authentication, particularly on accounts like Google, involves setting up a phone number for receiving OTPs and enabling recognition through prompts. It acts as a barrier against unauthorized access, even if your password is discovered. # Application-Specific Passwords 🔑 For using apps with your account, Google provides an option to create application-specific passwords, ensuring an extra layer of security. This is important if your phone with enabled apps is lost. By deleting these passwords remotely, you can protect your accounts and reset them on new devices. By understanding and using these methods, you can greatly improve the security of your personal and work digital environments.

parts.title: Introduction to Wireless Network Security
parts.body: Wireless networks have made communication more convenient but they are also more vulnerable to security threats compared to wired networks. These threats include eavesdropping, hacking, and misuse of unauthorized access points. It's important to ensure that wireless components like access points and network cards are secured using the latest security protocols and techniques. Wireless network security involves protecting data and devices from unauthorized access. Many wireless protocols, such as 802.11b/g/n, work at the physical and data link layers of the OSI model but still expose networks to potential threats. Security starts at the network layer, demanding logical security measures. Key vulnerabilities are physical network exposure, insecure Bluetooth, ZigBee, BLE connections, access points, and the general lack of robust encryption like WEP, WPA, WPA2, and WPA3.

parts.title: Installing and Binding SSL Certificate
parts.body: To install an SSL certificate, start by copying the generated CSR file text and submit it to the CA's website. Once verified, the CA sends the SSL certificate via email. Save and install this on your server following these steps: Go to Server Certificates, click Complete Certificate Request, fill in the domain and hosting info, and select the certificate file. Completing these steps installs the SSL on your server. After installation, assign the SSL to your desired website on the IIS Manager page. Expand to locate Sites, choose your site (e.g., Default Web Site), and access Bindings. Here, add a new binding, select HTTPS, and configure the IP and port (443). This binds SSL to your website, ensuring secure connections.

parts.title: Mobile Security and Platform Overview
parts.body: The section provides an overview of the increasing threats to mobile security, highlighting various types like spyware attacks, Trojan attacks, and malware like BotNet activities. It underscores the importance of mobile device security due to their integration into everyday activities, such as communication, browsing, and shopping. The discussion touches on key mobile platforms like Android and iOS, showing their dominance in the market with Android leading with over 74% market share. It elaborates on the evolution and characteristics of these mobile operating systems (OS), particularly focusing on Android. Developed by Google in collaboration through the Open Handset Alliance, Android is built on a modified Linux kernel and features numerous proprietary Google services. The section emphasizes the security challenges and the need for secure mobile practices given the widespread usage of smartphones, highlighting that security will drive future cybersecurity directives.
